questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding thrombi, except:

options.label: A
options.text: Arterial/ cardiac thrombi form at the sight of turbulence or endothelial injury

options.label: B
options.text: Thrombi are focally attached to the point of initiation

options.label: C
options.text: Arterial Thrombi propagate away from the heart

options.label: D
options.text: Venous Thrombi are formed due to stasis and extend in the direction of blood flow

questions.correct_answer: C. Arterial Thrombi propagate away from the heart
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Arterial Thrombi propagate away from the heart. Arterial thrombi tend to grow retrograde, i.e. they propagate towards the heart.

Highyeild:

Thrombosis and Virchow’s Triad: Thrombosis results due to: Endothelial injury Stasis or Turbulent blood flow Hypercoagulability of the blood. This is called Virchow's Triad . Arterial or cardiac thrombi usually begin at turbulence or endothelial injury sites , whereas venous thrombi characteristically occur at stasis sites . Thrombi are focally attached to the underlying vascular surface , particularly at the initiation . From here, arterial thrombi tend to grow retrograde , while venous thrombi extend in the direction of blood flow ; thus, BOTH propagate towards the heart .

questions.text: False statement regarding lines of Zahn is-

options.label: A
options.text: Lines of Zahn are seen grossly and microscopically

options.label: B
options.text: These signify antemortem clot

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Laminations signify that a thrombus is formed due to stasis

questions.correct_answer: D. Laminations signify that a thrombus is formed due to stasis
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Laminations signify that a thrombus is formed due to stasis Thrombi often have grossly and microscopically apparent laminations called lines of Zahn , pale platelet and fibrin deposits alternating with darker red cell–rich layers . Such laminations signify that a thrombus has formed in flowing blood . Their presence can therefore distinguish antemortem clots from the bland non-laminated clots that occur post-mortem . Post-mortem clots have a Chicken fat appearance due to the settlement of RBcs under the fact layer.

questions.text: All statements are true regarding arterial thrombi except:

options.label: A
options.text: These are frequently occlusive

options.label: B
options.text: These consist of platelets, fibrin RBC and degenerated leukocytes

options.label: C
options.text: Cerebral artery is the most common to be involved

options.label: D
options.text: These are superimposed on the rupture of atherosclerotic plaques or vascular injury

questions.correct_answer: C. Cerebral artery is the most common to be involved
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cerebral artery is the most common to be involved Arterial thrombi are frequently occlusive . The most common sites in decreasing order of frequency are the coronary, cerebral, and femoral arteries . They typically consist of a friable meshwork of platelets, fibrin, red cells, and degenerating leukocytes . Although these are usually superimposed on a ruptured atherosclerotic plaque , other vascular injuries like vasculitis, and trauma may as well be the underlying cause .

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding post-mortem clots except

options.label: A
options.text: Gelatinous in nature

options.label: B
options.text: Attached to the underlying vessel

options.label: C
options.text: It can sometimes be confused with antemortem venous thrombi

options.label: D
options.text: Upper part is yellow, while the lower part is dark red

questions.correct_answer: B. Attached to the underlying vessel
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Attached to the underlying vessel Postmortem clots can sometimes be mistaken for Antemortem Venous Thrombi . However, clots that form after death are gelatinous and have a dark red dependent portion where red cells have settled by gravity and a yellow “chicken fat” upper portion and are usually NOT attached to the underlying vessel wall .

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding DVT, except:

options.label: A
options.text: DVT can embolise the lungs

options.label: B
options.text: 50% of the cases are usually asymptomatic

options.label: C
options.text: It usually involves a large leg vein at or above the knee

options.label: D
options.text: Bed rest helps in the prevention of DVT

questions.correct_answer: D. Bed rest helps in the prevention of DVT
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bed rest helps in the prevention of DVT Prolonged Bed rest predisposes to Deep Vein Thrombosis.

Highyeild:

Venous Thrombosis: Most venous thrombi occur in the superficial or deep veins of the leg . Superficial venous thrombi typically occur in the saphenous veins in the setting of varicosities . Such thrombi can cause local congestion, swelling, pain, and tenderness, but rarely embolize, but predispose the overlying skin to develop infection and ulcers (varicose ulcers) . Deep venous thrombosis (DVT) involving one of the large leg veins— at or above the knee (e.g., the popliteal, femoral, and iliac veins) —is more serious because such thrombi more often embolise to the lungs and give rise to pulmonary infarction . DVTs are asymptomatic in approximately 50% of affected individuals and are recognised only in retrospect after embolisation . Common predisposing factors include: Bed rest and immobilisation Trauma Recent surgery (joint replacement especially) Trauma Obesity Malignancy Smoking OCP use Pregnancy and postpartum
